@vitorbaptista unfortunately your fix appears not to work under Python3 (see failing tests)

Importing any operator from `airflow.operators` is being deprecated because of creeping complexity. You should be seeing a warning like this:

```python

In [1]: import airflow
[2017-03-15 21:05:33,021] {__init__.py:56} INFO - Using executor LocalExecutor

In [2]: from airflow.operators import SubDagOperator
/Users/jlowin/git/airflow/airflow/utils/helpers.py:406: DeprecationWarning: Importing SubDagOperator directly from <module 'airflow.operators' from '/Users/jlowin/git/airflow/airflow/operators/__init__.py'> has been deprecated. Please import from '<module 'airflow.operators' from '/Users/jlowin/git/airflow/airflow/operators/__init__.py'>.[operator_module]' instead. Support for direct imports will be dropped entirely in Airflow 2.0.
  DeprecationWarning)
```

(looks like the module names got a little mangled at some point!)

So after thinking about this some more, I gave you some bad advice. You're caught in a tight place -- trying to adjust some deprecated behavior that's nonetheless maintained for backwards-compatibility reasons - so we need to awkwardly support both modes. 

Sorry to ask you to revise one more time, but I think the right way to do this is to leave the existing check and add an additional `or isinstance(task, SubDagOperator)` to the check, where `SubDagOperator` is properly imported as you're doing now. This way the legacy check is maintained for backwards compatibility and your way handles it properly going forward (and bonus points for putting a `#TODO remove in Airflow 2.0` over the legacy part of the check.)

Sorry for the confusion!

I'm showing up late in this discussion and find the original text at the top of this PR a bit confusing.

`ALL_SUCCESS` should mean `ALL_SUCCESS`. I don't think this is up for debate.

`ALL_SUCCESS_OR_SKIPPED` is a reasonable new trigger rule.

The real question is how `SKIPPED` states should propagate in virtue of trigger rules. I believe that the current behavior is that the branching operator recurses and marks tasks as `SKIPPED` on all of the branches it's not taking. That recursion part should probably not live in the operator, but in the scheduler. In the specific case of `ALL_SUCCESS` and one of the upstream tasks being `SKIPPED`, I think that the task should be `SKIPPED` if the branching operator did not already mark it as `SKIPPED` (in the case where a DAG changes shape in the meantime).

On a related note, what is the latest stable release? PyPI [shows 1.7.1.3](https://pypi.python.org/pypi/airflow/1.7.1.3). JIRA [doesn't have a release date](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/AIRFLOW/?selectedTab=com.atlassian.jira.jira-projects-plugin:summary-panel) for that version and [shows 2 unresolved issues for it](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/AIRFLOW/fixforversion/12336740/?selectedTab=com.atlassian.jira.jira-projects-plugin:version-summary-panel); it also shows [1.8.0 as having a release date of 2017-02-02](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/AIRFLOW/fixforversion/12339190/?selectedTab=com.atlassian.jira.jira-projects-plugin:version-summary-panel) and with 0 unresolved issues. There [is a Git tag for 1.8.0](https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/tags), but that tag seems to be getting overwritten regularly. (For example, it used to point at https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/commit/310fb589ae867ff2ec8b7ce3cc5b1659db4dad49, but was changed recently to point at https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/commit/f4760c320a29be62469799355e76efa42d0b6bb2.) (I'm unfamiliar with Apache's conventions, so am uncertain what source to consider the canonical reference.)

Latest stable is 1.7.1.3. Version 1.8.0 is being voted for release *right now*, and has gone through a number of release candidates (hence the tag changes). The likely confusion in JIRA is because 1.8.0 is (or will be soon) the first release since Airflow joined Apache.
